timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:typetools/checker-framework into accumulation-analysis

timeline.bodyText: Is there a test case that shows this halting at a non-receiver-returning method invocation?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Yes. See ~line 35 of SimpleFluent.java, for example.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: Could you add this test case?  Probably there will be a comment saying the code is safe and the checker currently issues a false positive warning.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: The test case exists, in SimpleFluent.java. It passes, because the Test Accumulation called-methods checker includes the other rules that allows the code to typecheck. I'll clarify this documentation to explicitly mention the need for another rule from the user if they want to handle this kind of case.
replies.author: kelloggm

replies.bodyText: The test case I had in mind contained a non-@This-returning method in the middle of a chain of @This-returning methods.  That is, there appear @This-returning methods both before and after it.  I added such a test case, and it fails.  It is poorly named m8 and you might want to rename it.
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: The reason that a.b().c() gets updated is different from why the other two expressions get updated.  I think that is worth calling out in the example.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Please add a test case for this.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: invokedMethod is not a method.  It's a call.  Therefore, the name is confusing.  It's also confusing that although methodInvocationNode and invokedMethod represent the same thing (just as different types), their names do not reflect this relationship.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
Please document the relationship between these variables.  It isn't obvious from the code.
Can you convert any of them from loop-carried dependencies into local variables within the loop?  If you can reduce the number of variables that the loop maintains, the loop will be easier to understand.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:typetools/checker-framework into accumulation-analysis

timeline.bodyText:
Should the remainder of this loop be equivalent to a recursive call to accumulate, just more efficient?
If so, could you add a comment to that effect?  (Or maybe even make it a recursive call to accumulate, which will be shorter and simpler code, though a bit less efficient.  If you do that, you can remove the while loop.)
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
This use of newAnno looks wrong to me.  newAnno was computed earlier for a later method call, and if the recursion goes past a non-@This-returning call, then the value should be reset rather than carried across that call.  I added a failing test case, m8, that illustrates incorrect behavior.
Should the recursion go through non-@This returning methods at all?
It is also a bit suspicious that no call of getUnionAnno occurs.  Could you write a comment saying why it is not needed, and it's OK to do complete replacement rather than GLB?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.message: rewrite accumulate to be recursive, and to use dataflow facts directly rather than the ATF

timeline.bodyText: Is this for loop guaranteed to execute exactly 0 or 1 times?  Should it assert that about the size of flowAnnos?  I think that each one must be either the accumulator or bottom; is that correct?  Is that worth verifying?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText:
Is this for loop guaranteed to execute exactly 0 or 1 times

Yes. I added an assertion.

I think that each one must be either the accumulator or bottom; is that correct?

Yes. My original version of this code included a test for it, but it was redundant with checking that the result of the call to getValueOfAnnotationWithStringArgument is non-null, so I removed it.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.message: try to make comment a bit more readable, and add an assertion about the size of the list
merge conflict with Mike's fix for the weird formatting
resolved issues and passed git pre-commit hooks
fixed all-test-jdk8 and all-test-jdk11 jobs in pipeline
Improve naming.  Make switch statements report errors.
Fixed contructor throw RuntimeException and javadoc
remove paragraph on disabling framework support

Rename MaybeThis to UnknownThis.

The name MaybeThis isn't bad, but the rest of the Checker Framework uses
the naming convention "Unknown" for the top type.
Improve Javadoc: add explanations, examples, links
removed frameworkSupport Interface and resolved comments
clean up some logic in type factory
use the merged version of the RR checker
add another test case that checks that RR support works as intended
add all remaining basic OCC tests that are relevant to a general accumulation analysis
add docs and remove debugging code
actually test the accumulate method, too, by making the test checker a very simple CM checker
remove code that should have been deleted
more docs, make Accumulation ATF constructor protected
Merge branch 'accumulation-analysis' of github.com:kelloggm/checker-framework into accumulation-analysis
add draft of manual section for building an accumulation checker

timeline.bodyText: FWIW I can't really read this lattice.  Is this a standard notation?
timeline.author: msridhar

replies.bodyText: The formatter messed this up. Sorry about that.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: Is it possible someone might want to build an accumulation checker that does not require returns-receiver reasoning?  Or shall we just assume any accumulation checker is also dealing with fluent APIs?
timeline.author: msridhar
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@ +package org.checkerframework.common.accumulation; + +import java.util.LinkedHashSet; +import org.checkerframework.common.basetype.BaseTypeChecker; +import org.checkerframework.common.returnsreceiver.ReturnsReceiverChecker; + +/** + * An accumulation checker is one that accumulates some property: method calls, keys into maps, etc. + * All accumulation analyses share some common features: their type systems are similar in + * structure, they need to reason about fluent APIs, and they need some way to easily add facts to + * the accumulation they are tracking. This accumulation analysis represents all facts as Strings. + * + *

Accumulation checkers are particularly interesting because they can represent many + * typestate-like properties, but do not require a precise alias analysis for soundness. + * + *

This class provides a basic accumulation checker that can be extended to implement a + * particular accumulation type system. The primary extension point is the constructor of {@link + * AccumulationAnnotatedTypeFactory}, which every subclass should override to provide custom + * annotations. + */ +public abstract class AccumulationChecker extends BaseTypeChecker { + + @Override + protected LinkedHashSet> getImmediateSubcheckerClasses() { + LinkedHashSet> checkers = + super.getImmediateSubcheckerClasses(); + checkers.add(ReturnsReceiverChecker.class);

replies.bodyText:
I assumed that anyone building an accumulation checker would want RR reasoning - there's not much reason to not include it. I suppose we could make it configurable, somehow (but then again, it already is - someone who didn't want the RR checker could override this method again!).
I'll add something to the javadoc that mentions it.
replies.author: kelloggm

replies.bodyText: There is the whole including a sub-checker doubles the overall checking time issue... 🙂But this is fine for now
replies.author: msridhar

timeline.bodyText: This will only be true if methods b and c are deterministic.  If they are not, only the estimate of a will be updated, and the types of a.b() and a.b().c() are computed in the type factory.  We should update the documentation to be clearer about this
timeline.author: msridhar

timeline.bodyText: As noted above, this call will do nothing when receiver is a method call that is not deterministic.  Not sure if we should change the implementation logic to reflect this more clearly.  Nothing incorrect happens now, but it may confuse future readers of the code
timeline.author: msridhar

timeline.message: some javadoc that I missed before

timeline.bodyText: Can we add a bit more detail on what this tree annotator is actually doing?  Like the example we give in the transfer function documentation.  This can be in the class documentation or the docs of visitMethodInvocation().
timeline.author: msridhar

replies.bodyText: I added it to the docs for getMethodInvocation()
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.message: improve docs on the tree annotator

timeline.bodyText: Wait, isn't the point that this annotator takes the receiver type and "accumulates in" the current method invocation?
timeline.author: msridhar

replies.bodyText: Only the Object Construction Checker does that. This version is simpler - all it does it make the return type match the receiver type if the method returns this. The TestAccumulationChecker handles actually accumulating method calls differently than the OCC, also - note that it does the actual accumulation in the Transfer class.
replies.author: kelloggm

replies.bodyText: I get it now.  Since the transfer function computes the complete accumulated type for the most deeply-nested receiver, all the type factory has to do is to copy that type to the return value for each call and it will get bubbled up.
replies.author: msridhar

timeline.bodyText:
What are the requirements for top and bottom?

Must they be instances of accumulator?  If top must be, I don't see the point of passing it explicitly.
Must they be distinct from accumulator?
Must they have a value field of String[] type?  The code seems to assume that top does, but I wonder if that assumption is warranted.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: values is used/aliased without being copied.  That can be OK, but is worth documenting (or changing if it is not an intended part of the design).
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I think that is only the case if an explicit array is passed. I added a note to the documentation.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: How about abstracting this into a field, to slightly improve efficiency?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: AnnotatedTypeFactories must not put subchecker type factories into fields. I have learned this the hard way before. In many other checkers, I've created a getSpecificSubchecker() method for each subchecker, but I didn't think that was really necessary here. See the documentation for getTypeFactoryOfSubchecker(): https://github.com/typetools/checker-framework/blob/master/framework/src/main/java/org/checkerframework/framework/type/GenericAnnotatedTypeFactory.java#L1585
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: How is this related to TOP and BOTTOM?  Is it definitely true of TOP, or only possibly true?  Is it definitely false of BOTTOM?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: It is definitely false of both. I think the documentation is clear, with the changes I've made elsewhere to make clear that the top, bottom, and accumulator annotations are expected to be distinct.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: Please use a more specific verb than "handles".
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: What does "Mandatory" mean here?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Java requires you to write a constructor for classes that don't have a default constructor. It is therefore "mandatory" to write one. More to the point, there's nothing to say about this constructor - it just calls super - but Javadoc is required. I never know what to write in these cases, so I write something inane to satisfy the checker.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: This comment may be true, but it doesn't say what the method does.  should it be "... then give a method invocation the same type as the receiver"?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I removed the comment on the method, and moved this into a list of the rules the annotator is responsible for implementing.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: "i.e." implies they are the same.  They are .equals(), but not ==, I think:  the side effects won't affect the invoked method.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: The comment about the return type of the invorked method is not true for polymorphic methods.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
I have a strong negative reaction to assignments within conditionals.

They are surprising and therefore liable to be overlooked or misinterpreted, especially given that "=" is a mathematical symbol for equality.
They are hard to reason about.

Please rewrite this code to avoid assignments within conditionals.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: This particular code snippet is hard to read either way, and using an assignment within a conditional less verbose. Nevertheless, I've changed it to comply with the Checker Framework's typical code style, because an assignment within a conditional will be more confusing if they are not commonly used in a particular code base.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: I am concerned about this call.  It is possible that receiverAnno is higher in the hierarchy than type, and so this would move the type up in the hierarchy (and override the method specification) rather than refining it.  Should this be GLB instead?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Good catch!
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: top is either identical to, or equivalent in the type hierarchy to, acc().  So I would add "= acc()" here.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
This is assumes that TOP has no value field, or might have no value field.
That's rather subtle.  To make this (and other) code easier to read, please create a method isTop and use it.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
The use of LinkedHashSet seems pointless here, because a1Val will be in the wrong order afterward -- and anyway, createAccumulatorAnnotation always sorts its argument.
How about one of these?

make a1Val a TreeSet
make a1Val a LinkedList and instead of doing addAll, do a mergesort merge step?  That can be done efficiently in O(n) time.

With either of these approaches, you can have a private createAccumulatorAnnotationFromSorted routine that takes a sorted list and doesn't need to call sort.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText:
With either of these approaches, you can have a private createAccumulatorAnnotationFromSorted routine that takes a sorted list and doesn't need to call sort.

I don't think this is a good idea. Arrays#sort is extremely optimized, and isn't going to spend very long to verify that an input array is sorted (O(n)) time, especially with such small arrays. I would prefer the safety of guaranteeing that the values of accumulator annotations are always sorted, even in the presence of bugs in the implementation, to the (extremely small) speedup you're proposing.
replies.author: kelloggm

replies.bodyText: To follow up on this, I just looked through how the Value Checker handles subtyping, etc. between @StringVal annotations, and I'm going to do the same thing here. It uses List rather than converting to sets in the QualifierHierarchy, and sorts and removes at the same time by converting to a TreeSet and back in the method that produces new StringVal annotations.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText:
This does not have to be a LinkedHashSet.  A HashSet will give the same results.  Though with a LinkedHashSet (or just a LinkedList for both variables is more efficient), you can do an O(n) instead of O(n log n) pass to remove duplicates, and then call a createAccumulatorAnnotationFromSorted routine to avoid subsequent calls to sort.
(More generally, it seems the code is trying to retain order to reduce the need for sorting, but then it does not take advantage of that (except insofar as sort may run faster on a partially-sorted array).
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: This uses a different test for top than !AnnotationUtils.hasElementValue(a1, "value") above.  Abstract it out into a method call, throughout.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: For consistency with how bottom is tested here and throughout, I changed all the checks for top to this one. I don't see the point of another procedure call that is just a wrapper for this call to AnnotationUtils#areSame
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: Since both lists are sorted, this can use an O(n) algorithm rather than the O(n^2) algorithm in List.containsAll.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: What does "Required" mean to convey here?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: see my comment about "mandatory" above. In my opinion, there's no need for Javadoc for these constructors.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: The first sentence says this method is about receivers, but a.b().c() is not the receiver nor within the reciever.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Thanks for pointing this out. This method didn't actually do what it said it did. I've consolidated the two accumulate methods, and their documentation should now be accurate. There was a corresponding error in TestAccumulationTransfer where accumulate was called on the method invocation (i.e. the return type), not the receiver, as it should have been. These two errors together allowed the tests to pass.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: Does "not affected" mean they are not updated, or they are updated as if all the methods had been deterministic, or they are updated (not "not updated"), but maybe in a different way than if all the methods had been deterministic?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Please be more specific.  Is this union?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: getNewAnno is a vague name that I found confusing at call sites.  Please rename it.  Should "New" in the name be replaced by "Glb"?  (Or possibly by "Union"?)
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I prefer "combined", but if that's still confusing I can change it to "union", which I think sounds weird when you say it out loud
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: How can !typeFactory.isAccumulatorAnnotation(oldAnno) be true?  Is that an error?  Or is it a funny way to test for BOTTOM and (in some type systems) TOP?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: It was a funny way to test for bottom or top. It turns out it isn't even necessary, so I removed it.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.message: make explicit the requirements on the top and bottom types
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:typetools/checker-framework into accumulation-analysis
Comment tweaks and a few logic simplifications
Merge branch 'accumulation-analysis' of github.com:kelloggm/checker-framework into accumulation-analysis

timeline.bodyText:
I don't see the need for a distinct top annotation.  I think that users can use @Accum() instead of @AccumTop.

Fewer annotations means less work for implementers and less for users to learn (less documentation to read).
"Top" is type system jargon.  Let's avoid that were possible.
It's confusing to users to have two different ways to express the same concept: @Accum() and @AccumTop.  I am also concerned that error messages will refer to @AccumTop when the users wrote @Accum(), which may confuse them.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: This is a good idea. I modeled the general accumulation type system on @CalledMethods, which has a separate top type, but I'm no longer convinced it's needed there, either.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: Facts like the existence of a single argument named "value" are testable in this method.  Users are likely to violate the requirements, unfortunately.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: That's a good point. I've added tests for all these requirements.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: What is the reason for permitting null as a value?  It is not used in the given code.  I think client code will be clearer if it uses Collections.emptyList(); it isn't obvious what null would be a special value for (a user might think it means bottom).  And, having two ways to accomplish the same goal can be confusing.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: It's usually clearer to name rules rather than number them.  That also insulates against renumbering or reordering.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Minor: leastUpperBound uses else if rather than a second if.  We might as well make them consistent to avoid readers doing a double-take.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
How can this happen?  (Maybe if there are other types than top, accumulator, and bottom?  But in that case clients should either use a different type hierarchy or should ensure that other types never flow to here.)
I suggest making this throw an exception rather than silently returning bottom.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Same question as above about whether this should be an error.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: "any deterministic methods": they might follow it, as in a.b().nondet().c().d() where b, c, and d are deterministic.  Do the values go through nondet() and affect all of b(), c(), and d()?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: yes, as long as nondet returns @This. I think this is just an imprecision caused by the dataflow framework rather than something fundamental, since the RR information should make the fact that the method isn't known to be deterministic irrelevant.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: "the ultimate receiver": this isn't clear.  I think you mean a in your examples, but I'm not sure.  The receiver value is identical, so I'm not sure what this means.  It's only the expressions that differ.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I do mean a. Really, what was meant was the first receiver expression that isn't an invocation of a method that returns its receiver. I'll update the text.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: Why is asList called?  The callee, getCombinedAnno, will make a copy anyway.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: This is no longer a concern with the other changes I've made.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: The documentation is clear, but I still find "getCombinedAnno" unclear since it's not the annotations that are being combined (lubbed) but the values that are being combined (unioned).  I would change "Combined" in the method name to "glb" or "union" or "accumulated".
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Why does this method treat null specially?  Are there places that null is more convenient to call?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
Is the logic in these lines similar to that in visitMethodInvocation?  If so, consider abstracting it out.
Or, since getCombinedAnnotation is only called once, you could create a method getAnnotationMirror that calls getAnnotatedType and then calls this logic.  That seems like a logical place for it, and then this method could just take an AnnotationMirror as an argument.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I rewrote the logic here to make it clear that they're not quite the same - in the annotated type factory, it's not necessary to check for the annotation mirror being null, but here it is. So I don't think there's any need to abstract the one or two lines they share.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: I think this is a way of saying "not top or bottom".  It's surprising that combining any A with top has the same effect as combining A with bottom.  Is that intentional?  Should combining A with bottom lead to bottom?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I rewrote this method to make this test unnecessary (it now uses GLB).
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:typetools/checker-framework into accumulation-analysis
remove the need for a separate top type, and other miscellaneous improvements that go along with that
add defensive logic to AccATF constructor to check that the accumulator annotation matches the requirements
Code review changes, mostly to documentation

timeline.bodyText:
"argument" should be "element".
The test also fails if it has zero elements, so the message may be misleading.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: This check, and the next one, are not about the annotation but about its value element, so the string created by rejectMalformedAccumulator is imprecise and possibly confusing.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: A UserError is when a user passed wrong arguments to the Checker Framework.  It can be corrected by changing the run-time invocation.  A bug in the source code of a checker should be thrown as a BugInCF., even if that source code was written by someone other than the main Checker Framework developers.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: "the chain" isn't really defined.  Can you define that term before you start discussing the behavior of the method?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
Why is it important to mention that the method is deterministic?
I think every method that returns its receiver is deterministic, so this would be a vacuous test and it's confusing why it is mentioned as an extra condition.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I think Manu made this point at some point, which is why we added it to the documentation. I agree it is distracting. @msridhar do you think removing any mention of determinism is okay here - it is a general fact about how dataflow works rather than something specific to how accumulation analysis works.
replies.author: kelloggm

replies.bodyText: Yes we can remove the mention of determinism
replies.author: msridhar

timeline.bodyText: Please remove these comments, or indicate how they are actionable.  For example, is the programmer supposed to keep the two versions of the test in sync by making a duplicate pull request on the other repository?
timeline.author: mernst

+// Copied from the Object Construction Checker.

timeline.author: mernst

timeline.message: efficiency improvements Mike asked for, as best as I can tell
update some comments, add failing test
